column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.FoR|FrameType
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Groundobject|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Target|
#Text=By the time I set out to cross the Moor in November, Coruisk's rich summer light had ceded to autumn's browns.
#Text=The air was cooler, and in place of the long evenings of July and August were quick dusks.
#Text=I had hoped for an early onset of winter, because I wanted to make an ice-bound traverse of the Moor, following its frozen waterways from one side to the other, on skis or even ice-skates.

#Text=This was something which I knew had been done once before, in the 1950s, and I greatly liked the idea of keeping to a single element for the crossing, of using only water to cross such an expanse of earth.
#Text=But my father, who had agreed to accompany me on the crossing, pointed out two minor problems with my plan: neither of us could ice-skate, and the weather was damp, so we would sink.
#Text=I acknowledged the force of his logic; walking it would have to be.
#Text=We caught the sleeper-train north together from London.
#Text=The romance of the train, its Edwardian miracle of conjuring you to a different land while you sleep, was still perceptible.

#Text=We left Euston Station — fast-food outlets, the tannoy's squash-ball bing-bong, crushed beer cans in corners, the shifty body-mass of the crowds — and woke to chilly air, white mist and a stag disappearing into the drizzle.
#Text=Fog pooled in the low ground.
#Text=At Rannoch Station, we stepped down from the train and on to the Moor.
#Text=That morning, we began to learn the habits and the obligations of the Moor, its resistance to straight lines of progress.
#Text=As Murray knew, going on the Moor is slow, to be measured in hours, not miles.
#Text=Much of the Moor is loch, and much is peat hag, and between the lochs and the peat hags bog streams wriggle, their water dyed black and shiny as oil.
#Text=We leapt from hag to hag, jumped peat crevasses and picked our way through the maze-work of stream and tussock.
#Text=Later, crossing a nameless river, I saw a big trout arrow across its pool and set chevrons rippling out over the surface.
#Text=Here and there, sunk in the peat, we came across the big swooping roots of ancient pine trees, thousands of years old.
#Text=How I would love to have climbed one of those great pines, I thought.

#Text=Peatbogs are so preservative of wood that, during the Second World War, the US Navy used 3,000-year-old white cedar logs, recovered from sphagnum bog in New Jersey, to build the hulls of their motor-torpedo boats.
#Text=From one of the stumps I took a loose dolphin-shaped fragment of wood, stained a deep brown by the peat.
#Text=In another black bank, I found a white stone, bedded like an eyeball.
#Text=I brushed it clean, and turned it in my hand as I walked.
#Text=The Moor's vastness and self-similarity affected our perception of distance.
#Text=Objects and movements showed more clearly in its spareness.

#Text=So extensive was the space within which we were moving that when I glanced up at the mountains west of the Moor, to try to gauge the distance we had come, it seemed as though we had not advanced at all: that, like explorers walking against the spin of pack ice, our feet fell exactly where we had lifted them.
#Text=Hours into the day, we stopped for shelter in a ruin named on our map as Tigh Na Cruaiche.
#Text=A rusted iron brazier stood in one corner.
#Text=Otherwise, the interior was empty.
#Text=It smelt green.
#Text=We sat on stones, and looked out through the doorless entrance.

#Text=Beyond the series of wooded islands slung across the centre of Loch Laidon we could see the Black Corries — the high holding grounds of deer, snow and fog — and the air which gathered in them had a deep cold blueness of tone.
#Text=I thought enviously of Murray, who had returned after the war to cross the Moor on a hot August day, with only his dog for company.
#Text=Halfway across, he had taken off all his clothes, put them in his pack, walking naked for the rest of the day, bathing here and there in pools and loch bays.
#Text=Perhaps, I daydreamed, on the right winter day bright sun, no wind — it might be possible to combine the traverses, and ice-skate naked from one side of the Moor to the other...

#Text=Later, on the top of a fifty-foot-high knoll, we sat and ate black rye bread with cheese, watching rain fronts gather miles away in the mouth of Glen Coe and then billow towards us over the ground.
#Text=Velvety rags of lichen hung from the rocks on the drumlin and rippled as wind passed over them.
#Text=My father pointed west: a kestrel, hunting fast over the ground.
#Text=Then it stopped, hung, collapsed its wings and dropped hard into the heather.

#Text=That far into the Moor, the vast space we were in resolved the land around us into bacon-like bands: a stripe of sky, a stripe of white cloud, a stripe of dark land, and below everything the tawny Moor.
#Text=The Moor's colours in that season were subtle and multiple.
#Text=Seen from a distance it was brindled; close up, it broke into its separate colours: orange, ochre, red, a mustardy yellow and, lacing everything, the glossy black of the peat.
#Text=It took us all that day to reach what I had come to think of as the Moor's centre, the Abhainn Bà — the point where the River Ba flows into Loch Laidon.
#Text=We stopped there, for dusk was spreading over the Moor, and pitched a small tent.
#Text=We lay talking in the dark: about the ground we had covered, the ground still to go, about the odd mixture of apprehension and awe that the Moor provoked in us both.
#Text=Our sleeping-place was cupped in a curve of the river, on a miniature floodplain that the winter spates had carved out and flattened: a shelter in the middle of the Moor's great space.
